newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanon ceasefire deal monitors to meet on Tuesday.
newsitem.headline: Lebanon ceasefire deal monitors to meet on Tuesday.

text.p: A five-nation monitoring group will meet on Tuesday to discuss a Lebanese complaint about Israeli shelling of civilian areas in south Lebanon, Lebanese official sources said on Monday.
They said the representatives of the United States, France, Lebanon, Syria and Israel will meet at the coastal village of Naqoura in Israel's south Lebanon occupation zone.

Lebanon had filed a complaint that Israeli shelling on Sunday wounded a civilian woman, the official sources said. Security sources said a woman was wounded in guerrilla-held Louwaizeh village while she was fleeing the bombardment.
The Israeli shelling was in retaliation for an attack by pro-Iranian Hizbollah guerrillas that killed an Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militiaman.

The monitoring committee was set up under a U.S.-brokered ceasefire understanding that ended a 17-day Israeli blitz against Hizbollah (Party of God) in Lebanon, in which some 200 people, mostly civilians, were killed.

The understanding bars Hizbollah and Israel from targetting civilian areas or launching attacks from civilian areas but allows guerrilla raids on Israeli troops in the south Lebanon zone and gives both sides the right to self-defence.
Last month, the five-nation committee said Israel was responsible for shelling a south Lebanon village and "deplored" the damage and injuries it caused.
